did.abstract: Socialist Labor Party member, later member of the League for Socialist Reconstruction. Correspondence, campaign files, audio-tapes, and other materials largely concerning his work with the State Central Committee of the Socialist Labor Party and Socialist Reconstruction, 1928-1992; and collected family materials including letters and memoirs of Levi Muncy, soldier during the Civil War; also photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers of Ralph Muncy (donor no. 4010) began coming to the library in 1963.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Ralph W. Muncy papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Ralph Muncy, socialist, educator, forester, civil engineer, and avid genealogist, was born April 26, 1902 in Cedar, Michigan, the son of John Irvin and Maud Ackley Muncy. After graduating from Ann Arbor High School in 1919, Muncy received a bachelor's degree in forestry from the University of Michigan in 1923. In 1930, Muncy received a teaching certificate from the University's School of Education. Best known for his ardent activities, Muncy was a member of the Socialist Labor Party (1930-1970) and later as a member of an offshoot party known as the Industrial Union Party (1970-1992). Muncy's sympathies for the working class were planted early. In the 1920s, his father, an automotive engineer, took young Ralph into the Studebaker plant in Detroit where he worked. While normally a soft spoken man, his father shouted and cursed at the workers, explaining to Ralph that this was the only way to treat the men. This episode made a lasting impression on Muncy.

Muncy, between 1952 and 1970, served as both secretary and chair of the Socialist Labor Party (SLP). Eventually disillusioned with the SLP because he believed that the party was diluting its program and 'cozying up' to capitalism, Muncy left the party in 1970 and was instrumental in the founding conference, in Ann Arbor, of Socialist Reconstruction (reorganized in 1981 as the Industrial Union Party). The membership of this new party consisted of former members of the S.L.P. and others who subscribed to Socialist Industrial Unionism as the foundation of a new society and form of government based upon public ownership of the means of production.

During his tenure as a member of each party, Muncy ran unsuccessfully for various state offices including Governor (1956 and 1982), Attorney General (1954 and 1960), Secretary of State, Highway Commissioner (1957), and Superintendent of Public Education. Muncy also ran for the U.S. Senate in 1966 and the U.S. Congress in 1968. Muncy wrote extensively on socialism and contributed to various socialist publications, as well as to a number of Michigan and national newspapers. He also lectured on socialism in CCC (Civilian Conservation Corps) camps during the 1930s.

Muncy's wife, Lydia Baird Muncy, born February 10, 1902 in Marine City, Michigan was the daughter of William Baird and Grace Low Baird. She shared her husband's interest in the socialist cause. Besides running on the party ticket for a position on the Board of Regents of the University of Michigan in 1968, Lydia Muncy was an active speaker appearing as a guest lecturer for such groups as the League of Women Voters on several occasions.

In addition to his activities with the Socialist Labor Party and the Industrial Union Party, Muncy practiced forestry as a private consultant and as an employee of the United States Forest Service until 1940. Subsequently, he was engaged as a civil engineer, in which capacity he was employed by General Motors, the Great Lakes Steel Corporation, and McNamee, Porter & Seeley Civil Engineering of Ann Arbor.

Muncy was also an avid genealogist and researched his own family genealogy extensively. He belonged to a number of historical societies including the Washtenaw County Historical Society (Mich.), the Historical Society of Michigan, and the Thomas Minor Society. Muncy was in charge of the newsletter for the Washtenaw County Historical Society and gave some lectures at the Society. Muncy also served as the historian for his Ann Arbor High School class and edited an alumni newsletter. Ralph Muncy died in March 1992, at the age of 89.

scopecontent.p: The Ralph Muncy collection consists primarily of papers relating to his interest in socialist political activities. A smaller portion of the collection documents the involvement of his wife, Lydia B. Muncy, in the socialist cause. Together they also collected materials relating to the history of their families (Muncy-Baird). Included is much original family material dating back into the nineteenth century. The Ralph Muncy papers have been arranged into the following series: Correspondence; Topical Files; and Ralph Muncy and Lydia Baird Muncy Personal.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series has been divided into two subseries: by date and by name of correspondent. The correspondents were largely individuals associated with Muncy while active first with the Socialist Labor Party and then the Socialist Reconstruction Party. The researcher should note that there is considerable overlap between the chronological and subject correspondence files and should thus consult each of the subseries.

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files series relates to the activities and administration of the Socialist Labor Party, the Socialist Reconstruction Party, its successor, League for Socialist Reconstruction, and the Industrial Union Party. Each of these subseries includes notes, minutes, clippings, some correspondence, printed matter, and ephemera. In addition, the Socialist Labor Party subseries includes sound recordings of meetings, debates, and radio presentations. Again, the researcher should note the overlapping of files.

Ralph Muncy and Lydia Baird Muncy Personal

scopecontent.p: The Ralph Muncy and Lydia Baird Muncy Personal series (1830[?]-1945) is divided into five subseries: Muncy/Baird Family Photographs, Letters, Memorabilia; Muncy Family Genealogy; personal and collected photographs; topical files; and scrapbooks.

The majority of the alphabetically arranged Muncy/Baird Family Photographs, Letters, Memorabilia subseries consists of letters dating between 1865-1916, as well as typescripts and photocopies of original letters. Most of the letters are addressed to Levi Muncy, Ralph W. Muncy's grandfather, while some are addressed to other Muncy family members including Caroline Kegg Muncy (Levi's wife) and Irvin and Leander Muncy (Levi and Caroline's sons) as well as various Kegg family members. The folders containing letters are arranged alphabetically by sender, with the individual letters arranged chronologically. The senders are mostly relatives of Levi, but there are also two folders of letters from friends and tradesmen. Key senders include Andrew J. Bates (Levi's uncle), Sarah Van Curen Compton (Levi's half-sister or step-sister[?]), Caroline Muncy, Irvin Muncy, Elizabeth Noggle (Levi's half-sister or step-sister[?]), and Catherine Van Curen (Levi's step-mother[?]). The letters appear to be a rich resource for Civil War era and turn of the century social history research. Besides family matters (e.g. births, deaths, and illnesses), the letters discuss farming and hunting practices, household chores, and the price and availability of land. One letter (Irvin Muncy to Caroline Muncy, 1909 February 21) talks about a revival in Boston in 1909.

Two folders worthy of note in this subseries are "Levi Muncy's memoirs, n.d." and Recipes, 1861-?. Levi Muncy's memoirs begin in 1858 when he goes west with his brother and go on to describe Levy's experiences as a soldier in the U.S. Army during the Civil War (e.g. at Vicksburg and Chickasaw bluffs). The Recipes folder contains a "Honey Receipt," as well as the ingredients for several home remedies.

The Muncy Family Genealogy subseries contains files of material gathered by Ralph Muncy regarding his family's genealogy. Included are correspondence between Muncy and various genealogical research centers and historians as well as photocopies of census records and excepts from biographical reference sources and county histories.

The personal and collected photographs subseries includes photographs of Ann Arbor and Washtenaw County (Mich.), as well as many photographs relating to Ralph Muncy as a student at the University of Michigan and Lydia Baird Muncy and her career as a teacher.

scopecontent.p: The Scrapbooks subseries (1920-1924) contains two scrapbooks, one compiled by Ralph and Lydia to commemorate their days at Ann Arbor High School and at the University of Michigan, and the other by Lydia Baird Muncy which contains mementos of her years as a student at the University of Michigan (e.g., commencement program, various social invitations, news clippings, photos, and concert programs).
